image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

props.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: A silhouette of a man in profile. Behind him is a composite of images including a plane, a CCTV camera, police lights and a car.

props.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: 'X' went undercover to take down organised crime. He says he's been abandoned

image.altText: A bushfire is seen in the background behind a sandbar on a quiet beach

props.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling multiple blazes in Victoria while an emergency warning has been issued for Flinders Island in Tasmania's north-east. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria and Tasmania reach emergency level as residents told to keep watch

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Daniel Miles Around 2,000 properties in East Gippsland are without power as more than 600 firefighters battle ongoing bushfires. Volunteer crews from across outer Metropolitan Melbourne and Geelong are travelling to the fire front to assist local volunteers fighting the Briagolong and Loch Sport blazes. Country Fire Authority chief fire officer Jason Heffernan told ABC Victorian Mornings some reprieve was expected in the next couple of hours (from 10am AEDT). "I'm most concerned about the [forecast] wind change," he said. "We do know that when the frontal system comes through and there is that change, that it can occur very rapidly, and there's generally an increase in wind speeds when that happens. "What was the flank of the fire this morning will become the head of that fire and head in the Glenaladale type direction." Power company Ausnet confirmed that around 2,000 properties were without power. Ausnet Spokesperson Nicci De Ryk said the company had workers ready to assess the damage once it was safe to do so. "There might be one or two wire power poles that have been impacted, but because this is an active fire we can't gain access to check," she said. "But we've certainly got the staff ready, we've got a helicopter ready as well." In Loch Sport, around 80 residents are taking shelter at the local pub. The manager of the town's Foodworks supermarket, Nicole, told ABC Victorian Mornings that residents were faring well. "There's a lot stress, I must admit, of the fear of the unknown, basically," she said. "Especially now the power's out, but we're trying to reassure people that things will be OK. "We can see smoke and flames and you can hear the firies. "We're at the middle of town and they're down at the start of town when you come in."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Thousands of homes lose power in Eastern Victoria as firies warn of 'dynamic' situation

children.content: Reporting by Daniel Miles
Around
2,000 properties in East Gippsland
are without power as more than 600 firefighters battle ongoing bushfires.
Volunteer crews from across outer Metropolitan Melbourne and Geelong are travelling to the fire front to assist local volunteers fighting the Briagolong and Loch Sport blazes.
Country Fire Authority chief fire officer
Jason Heffernan
told ABC Victorian Mornings
some reprieve was expected
in the next couple of hours (from 10am AEDT).
"I'm most concerned about the [forecast] wind change," he said.
"We do know that when the frontal system comes through and there is that change, that it can occur very rapidly, and there's generally an increase in wind speeds when that happens.
"What was the flank of the fire this morning will become the head of that fire and head in the Glenaladale type direction."
Power company Ausnet confirmed that around 2,000 properties were without power.
Ausnet Spokesperson
Nicci De Ryk
said the company had workers ready to assess the damage once it was safe to do so.
"There might be one or two wire power poles that have been impacted, but because this is an active fire we can't gain access to check," she said.
"But we've certainly got the staff ready, we've got a helicopter ready as well."
In Loch Sport, around 80 residents are taking shelter at the local pub.
The manager of the town's Foodworks supermarket,
Nicole
, told ABC Victorian Mornings that residents were faring well.
"There's a lot stress, I must admit, of the fear of the unknown, basically," she said.
"Especially now the power's out, but we're trying to reassure people that things will be OK.
"We can see smoke and flames and you can hear the firies.
"We're at the middle of town and they're down at the start of town when you come in."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Daniel Miles Around 80 people are sheltering at the Loch Sport pub as fires continue to burn north-east of Morwell. Andy Gilham is the Incident Controller at Heyfield, overseeing firefighting efforts at both the Loch Sport and Briagolong fires. He said firefighters were prioritising work to save residents’ homes and critical public infrastructure. "We expect to be hard at this and for the [Loch Sport] community to be on high levels of alert for the bulk of the day and into early evening," he told ABC Victorian Mornings. Mr Gilham said a south-westerly wind change forecast later in the day will put pressure on that community. He said the change in wind will provide an area of burnt ground which will help firefighting efforts. "That's one of the area's there's been a lot of fuel modification works for this very reason," he said. Mr Gilham said the fire near Briagolong, which had grown to more than 17,000 hectares, had fire behaviour "indices near the severe end [of the scale]". "It's still some 6 kilometres away from townships … but will still continue to impact on private property," he said. "What we saw in the early hours of this morning was the exact replica of the weather conditions on Sunday. "It’s still very active out there." Multiple schools and roads have closed across East Gippsland.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Around 80 people sheltering at Loch Sport pub

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lani Oataway Three firefighters remain in hospital after a tanker rolled while responding to a grass fire south of Bathurst in NSW over the weekend. Six Rural Fire Service members were in the truck when it rolled at a bend in White Rock Road. Three were able to get out, but three others needed to be removed by emergency services. RFS Inspector Ben Shepherd said it would be some time before those recovering in care at hospitals in Sydney and Orange will head home. "There's various injuries from fractures of the legs and arms, also some fractured ribs and punctured lungs, so albeit that they are quite serious, thankfully nothing that is life threatening." Inspector Shepherd said it is always hard to process when colleagues are injured on the job. "This can be a bit of a shock because we cast our memory back to those tragic circumstances obviously in 2019-20, so look it always hurts us both locally but also from a state-wide [level]."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Three injured firefighters recovering in hospital

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A huge statewide effort is underway to fight several out of control bushfires which are spreading across Gippsland. At least 650 firefighters are battling hot and windy weather conditions, with a cool change not expected until later this afternoon. A fire at Loch Sport jumped the Longford-Loch Sport Road and has burned 3,000 hectares. Electricity to the town has been cut and the only access in and out of the area has been closed. Incident controller Andy Gillan says it is too late to leave. "Those Loch Sport people please remain vigilant, shelter in place, enact your fire plans and if you're feeling uncomfortable in Loch Sport we encourage you to head down to the Marina Hotel. " You can keep up to date with the Gippsland fires here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Statewide effort underway as bushfires spread across Gippsland

featuredLink.title: With their only road out of town now cut by bushfire, residents prepare for possible evacuation by boat

"Those Loch Sport people please remain vigilant, shelter in place, enact your fire plans and if you're feeling uncomfortable in Loch Sport we encourage you to head down to the Marina Hotel. "
You can keep up to date with the Gippsland fires here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Late-night talk shows are returning after a five-month absence brought on by the Hollywood writers strike. CBS's The Late Show With Stephen Colbert, ABC's Jimmy Kimmel Live! and NBC's T he Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon were the first shows to leave the air when the writers strike began on May 2, and now will be among the first to return on Monday night. Comedian John Oliver got his first take on the strike out, exuberantly returning Sunday night to his Last Week Tonight show on HBO and delivering full-throated support for the strike. Oliver cheerily delivered a recap of stories from the last five months before getting serious, calling the strike "an immensely difficult time" for all those in the industry. "To be clear, this strike happened for good reasons. Our industry has seen its workers severely squeezed in recent years," Oliver said. "So, the writers guild went to strike and thankfully won. But, it took a lot of sacrifices from a lot of people to achieve that. "I am also furious that it took the studios 148 days to achieve a deal they could have offered on day one," Oliver said. He added that he hopes the writers contract would give leverage to other entertainment industry guilds – as well as striking car workers and employees in other industries – to negotiate better deals. Network late-night hosts will have their returns later on Monday. The writers were allowed to return to work last week after the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement on a three-year contract with an alliance of the industry's biggest studios, streaming services and production companies. Reporting by AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US late-night talk show hosts return after five-month absence

props.alt: Four white men in suits stand side by side.

children.content: Jimmy Fallon (left), Jimmy Kimmel, Seth Meyers and Stephen Colbert will be returning to their late night shows.
(AP)

he Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon
were the first shows to leave the air when the writers strike began on May 2, and now will be among the first to return on Monday night.
Comedian
John Oliver
got his first take on the strike out, exuberantly returning Sunday night to his Last Week Tonight show on HBO and delivering full-throated support for the strike.
Oliver cheerily delivered a recap of stories from the last five months before getting serious, calling the strike "an immensely difficult time" for all those in the industry.
"To be clear, this strike happened for good reasons. Our industry has seen its workers severely squeezed in recent years," Oliver said.
"So, the writers guild went to strike and thankfully won. But, it took a lot of sacrifices from a lot of people to achieve that.
"I am also furious that it took the studios 148 days to achieve a deal they could have offered on day one," Oliver said.
He added that he hopes the writers contract would give leverage to other entertainment industry guilds – as well as striking car workers and employees in other industries – to negotiate better deals.
Network late-night hosts will have their returns later on Monday.

The writers were allowed to return to work last week after the Writers Guild of America reached an agreement on a three-year contract with an alliance of the industry's biggest studios, streaming services and production companies.
Reporting by AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Open will take place over 15 days instead of 14, to try and reduce the amount of late-night finishes. It will start on a Sunday in 2024 and is scheduled to run from January 14- 28. You can read more on the extension here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Open extends to 15 days, to avoid late-night finishes

featuredLink.title: Australian Open set for shake-up to eliminate 'ridiculously late' finishes

children.content: The Australian Open will take place over 15 days instead of 14, to try and reduce the amount of late-night finishes.

You can read more on the extension here.

title.children: ASX falls sharply, Australian dollar sinks to 11-month low ahead of Reserve Bank decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The competition regulator has thrown up a hurdle to a potential healthcare takover deal. Australian Clinical Labs (ACL) wants to buy medical centre operator Healius. However, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commmission ( ACCC ) said today that it has "significant preliminary competition concerns", and that the deal could reduce competition for pathology services. ACL may need to sell off its approved collection centres (for pathology services) across the nation before the Healius buyout can be approved. "We are now seeking feedback from stakeholders on whether the draft undertaking offered by ACL would be capable of addressing the competition concerns," ACCC commissioner Stephen Ridgeway said. The proposed buyout may involve ACL divesting 60 of its pathology collection centres in Perth, 25 across regional Victoria, and 14 in the Northern Territory (subject to a final decision by the regulator). Shares of Healius fell 2.4% to $2.23, while Australian Clinical Labs is down 1.4% to $2.76.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Clinical's proposed takeover of Healius complicated by ACCC's demands

children.content: The competition regulator has thrown up a hurdle to a potential healthcare takover deal.
Australian Clinical Labs
(ACL) wants to buy medical centre operator
Healius
However, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commmission (
ACCC
) said today that it has "significant preliminary competition concerns", and that the deal could reduce competition for pathology services.
ACL may need to sell off its approved collection centres (for pathology services) across the nation before the Healius buyout can be approved.
"We are now seeking feedback from stakeholders on whether the draft undertaking offered by ACL would be capable of addressing the competition concerns," ACCC commissioner Stephen Ridgeway said.

The proposed buyout may involve ACL divesting 60 of its pathology collection centres in Perth, 25 across regional Victoria, and 14 in the Northern Territory (subject to a final decision by the regulator).
Shares of Healius fell 2.4% to $2.23, while Australian Clinical Labs is down 1.4% to $2.76.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: On this deeply negative day on the share market, only 12 stocks on the ASX 200 index are making any gains, including Graincorp, Neuren Pharmaceuticals and Computershare. In fact, most of them are making very small gains. There are far more stocks in the red including miners like Sayona Mining, De Grey Mining and West African Resources, and energy stocks like Karoon Energy and Santos. But it's the mega-cap stocks which are weighing most on the share market, like BHP (-2.1%), Rio Tinto (-1.9%), Fortescue Metals (-1.6%) and NAB (-1.3%). The other "big three" banks are down between 0.6% and 1%.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mining stocks among the worst performers on the ASX

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market is off to an abysmal start, with the ASX 200 down 1.6% to 6,920 points — its lowest level since March 20. In other words, it has dropped 112 points in the first half-hour of trade (taking the benchmark index below the 7,000 points mark). Every sector is posting losses, with energy and materials among the worst performers after substantial falls in the price of gold, iron ore and oil overnight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 drops to seven-month low

Every sector is posting losses, with energy and materials among the worst performers after substantial falls in the price of gold, iron ore and oil overnight.
